solution.p: Isolate x by "undoing" each operation in order: perform the opposite operations. \begin{aligned}[t] 3\sqrt{x-4} \amp = 15 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Divide both sides by 3.}}\\ \sqrt{x-4} \amp = 5 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Square both sides.}}\\ x-4 \amp = 25 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Add 4 to both sides.}}\\ x \amp = 29 \end{aligned} When we square both sides of an equation, we should check for extraneous solutions. 3\sqrt{\alert{29}-4} = 3\sqrt{25} = 3(5)=15 The solutions is 29.

Clear the fraction by multiplying both sides by (x-1). \begin{aligned}[t] \dfrac{24}{x-1} \blert{(x-1)} \amp = 4 \blert{(x-1)} \amp\amp \blert{\text{Multiply by}~(x-1).}\\ 24 \amp = 4(x-1) \amp\amp \blert{\text{Divide both sides by 4.}}\\ 6 \amp = x-1 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Add 1 to both sides.}}\\ 7 \amp = x \end{aligned} Substituting 7 into x-1, we see that 7 does not cause the denominator to be 0, so 7 is the solution.

introduction.p: Recall that the equation for a circle of radius r centered at the origin is x^2+y^2=r^2

ol.label: a
ol.li: Solve the equation ~x^2+y^2=9~ for y to get two functions.
Find two points on the circle that have x-coordinate 1.

li.p: \begin{aligned}[t] x^2+y^2 \amp = 9 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Subtract}~x^2~\text{from both sides.}}\\ y^2 \amp = 9 - x^2 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Take square roots.}}\\ y \amp = \pm \sqrt{9-x^2} \end{aligned} The two functions are ~y = \sqrt{9-x^2}~ and ~y = -\sqrt{9-x^2}~.
